required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Phosphatidylserine on Time Trial Performance in Trained Male Cyclists
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Phosphatidylserine on Time Trial Performance in Trained Male Cyclists

brief_summary.textblock: Phosphatidylserine is a phospholipid found in high concentrations in the brain and nervous tissues along with naturally occurring in many foods. It has been extensively studied for its effects on improving cognitive function, learning, memory and alleviating stress. However, more recently it has been proposed that phosphatidylserine could improve exercise capacity. The mechanisms of proposed action are difficult to distinguish because of the limited research and therefore the purpose of this study is to identify the proposed mechanism of action of phosphatidylserine supplementation and to establish whether these mechanisms will have an effect on time trial performance in trained male cyclists.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Participants matched on cycling time-trial performance and then randomly assigned to treatment or placebo groups
study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)
study_design_info.masking_description: The experiment will follow a double-blind design where all participants and investigators will be blinded to the treatments given.

primary_outcome.measure: 30 minute cycling time-trial power output on an electromagnetically-braked cycle ergometer
primary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline to 11 days post supplementation

secondary_outcome.measure: Oxygen consumption at four different exercise intensities (40, 50, 60 and 70% percent of maximal oxygen uptake) on an electromagnetically-braked cycle ergometer
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline to 11 days post supplementation
secondary_outcome.description: Evaluated using an online breath-by-breath gas analyser

secondary_outcome.measure: Respiratory exchange ratio at four different exercise intensities (40, 50, 60 and 70% percent of maximal oxygen uptake) on an electromagnetically-braked cycle ergometer
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline to 11 days post supplementation
secondary_outcome.description: Evaluated using an online breath-by-breath gas analyser

secondary_outcome.measure: Breathing frequency at four different exercise intensities (40, 50, 60 and 70% percent of maximal oxygen uptake) on an electromagnetically-braked cycle ergometer
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline to 11 days post supplementation
secondary_outcome.description: Evaluated using an online breath-by-breath gas analyser

secondary_outcome.measure: Minute ventilation at four different exercise intensities (40, 50, 60 and 70% percent of maximal oxygen uptake) on an electromagnetically-braked cycle ergometer
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline to 11 days post supplementation
secondary_outcome.description: Evaluated using an online breath-by-breath gas analyser

secondary_outcome.measure: Blood lactate concentration at four different exercise intensities (40, 50, 60 and 70% percent of maximal oxygen uptake) on an electromagnetically-braked cycle ergometer
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline to 11 days post supplementation
secondary_outcome.description: Obtained via capillary puncture and analysed using an automated analyser

secondary_outcome.measure: Blood glucose concentration at four different exercise intensities (40, 50, 60 and 70% percent of maximal oxygen uptake) on an electromagnetically-braked cycle ergometer
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline to 11 days post supplementation
secondary_outcome.description: Obtained via capillary puncture and analysed using an automated analyser

secondary_outcome.measure: Rating of perceived exertion at four different exercise intensities (40, 50, 60 and 70% percent of maximal oxygen uptake) on an electromagnetically-braked cycle ergometer
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline to 11 days post supplementation

secondary_outcome.measure: Heart rate at four different exercise intensities (40, 50, 60 and 70% percent of maximal oxygen uptake) on an electromagnetically-braked cycle ergometer
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline to 11 days post supplementation
secondary_outcome.description: Evaluated using a heart rate monitor

clinical_study.condition: The Focus of the Study is to Investigate the Effects of Phosphatidylserine Supplementation on Exercise Physiology and Cycling Time-trial Performance

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Cyclists
- Maximum oxygen uptake of at least 55 mL/kg/min
Exclusion Criteria:

eligibility.gender_description: All participants must be trained male cyclists
